text: we usually worked about 12 hours a day
and we had to go up and down the rows of
the field I woke up four o'clock every
morning and I was in there by 6:30 and I
wasn't out of there till about 8:00 8:30
later on that night I was topping the
sucker and cutting the flowers off the
tobacco and all oh my work for about
like like 12 10 hours every day except
Sundays well it will surprise many to
know that here in the United States in
places like North Carolina children as
young as 12 can work even 72 hours a
week here in the fields that is
something that is perfectly legal what
human rights groups are asking is is it
right when it comes to children working
in agriculture the u.s. is not complying
with International Labour Organization
conventions that regulate hazardous work
for children countries like Brazil and
India which are both major tobacco
producers worldwide prohibit kids under
18 from doing many tasks in tobacco
farming last summer Brandon and his
younger brother Fernando now 15 and 13
worked long days picking tobacco
business though so I would have him
winning you know four out cuz she was
struggling really bad I told my kids not
to do it but they wouldn't listen to me
they wanted to do what they considered
was their part but it must have hurt you
know bothered me it bothered me
especially when Fernando come home that
day sick because of the pesticides he
was wheezing and having problems
breathing and he was really really not
doing good most people when they were
working they put like trash bags on them
and they cut holes for their arms and
all in their head so the chemicals won't
be on them because if the chemicals get
on you later in the day when like it
like it's really really sunny it'll
start burning you many of the children
we interviewed reported symptoms
consistent with acute nicotine poisoning
so nausea vomiting headache
dizziness lightheadedness about half the
children we interviewed said they saw
tractors coming through fields where
they were working spraying pesticides
there are laws here to say if children
work it does have to be outside school
hours but tobacco farmers like Joey
Scott say it's part of tradition the
children work in the fields anyway and
it's good for them well I was raised as
a child on a tobacco farm and I attended
a lot of my babies through the work that
I worked alongside my parents and
grandparents by being in the fields
understanding the everyday struggles
that the farmers have to go through as
far as being safe I was safe my parents
felt safe enough for me to be here and
I'm an eighth generation farmer and my
kids are not generation farmers and
that's the way they learned their
responsibility is through helping our
family on our family farm last year I
really didn't want to work but you know
I had to he's the man in the house and
all he's yeah he's I have to do what I
can to take care of my family and I'm
willing to do whatever that's it to to
the damn phone take them away that's
going to change
